questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with complaints of glare and diminution of vision for 3 months. On examination, you notice the following appearance Choose the correct statement regarding the correct diagnosis.

options.label: A
options.text: The Iris shadow test becomes positive only when the whole cortex is involved.

options.label: B
options.text: Patients see better in dark surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: Characterized by saucer-shaped opacities in the center of the posterior cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: Vision loss occurs at a late stage.

questions.correct_answer: D. Vision loss occurs at a late stage.
questions.explanation:
Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery). (Option D)
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils. (Option B)

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract). (Option C)
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas(Option A)
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

questions.text: An elderly male diabetic patient came with loss of vision in the left eye associated with pain in the left eye. On examination, the left eye appears red, and visual acuity- Perception of light+ and IOP is raised in the same eye. The patient gives history of blurring and diminution of vision for the past 1 year. The slit lamp examination is given below. Choose the correct diagnosis and appropriate pathophysiology for this patient.
questions.correct_answer: C. Phacolytic glaucoma - Secondary open-angle glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma

Phacolytic Glaucoma

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork.

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

questions.text: Match the type of cataract with the etiology Type of cataract Etiology a. Posterior subcapsular 1. Glassblowers b. Anterior subcapsular-granular 2. Miotics c. Posterior cortical 3. Steroids
Which surgical approach is the most appropriate for a 65 year old male with a visually significant cataract and a history of narrow-angle glaucoma?

A 70-year-old woman presents for cataract surgery in her right eye. She has moderate cataract density with some nuclear sclerosis and a clear cornea. She expresses a strong desire for a procedure that minimizes recovery time and provides optimal visual outcomes. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the advantage of Phacoemulsification Over Manual SICS?

options.label: A
options.text: Manual SICS typically requires a smaller incision compared to Phacoemulsification.

options.label: B
options.text: Manual SICS allows for faster visual recovery compared to Phacoemulsification.

options.label: C
options.text: Manual SICS is less suitable for very hard cataracts compared to Phacoemulsification.

options.label: D
options.text: Manual SICS usually results in a higher level of postoperative astigmatism compared to Phacoemulsification.

questions.correct_answer: D. Manual SICS usually results in a higher level of postoperative astigmatism compared to Phacoemulsification.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Manual SICS

Phacoemulsification

Procedure Type

Extracapsular Cataract Extraction (ECCE)

Extracapsular Cataract Extraction (ECCE)

Incision Type

Self-sealing, valvular, sclerocorneal tunnel incision

Self-sealing, valvular, sclerocorneal tunnel incision or clear corneal incision.

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia (can be performed under)

Local anesthesia (can also be performed under topical anesthesia)

Nucleus Removal Method

Manually extracted through the incision after being maneuvered out of the capsular bag

Fragmented using an ultrasonic probe and then aspirated

Suitability

(Option C)

Suitable for all cataract densities, including very hard cataracts

Typically requires a smaller incision, less suitable for very hard cataracts

Visual Recovery

(Option B)

Slower visual recovery, delayed return to optimal vision

Faster visual rehabilitation due to smaller incision and reduced tissue manipulation

Astigmatism

(Option A)

Higher levels of surgically induced astigmatism, larger incision

Less postoperative astigmatism due to smaller incision size

Complication Risks
  • Lower risk of nuclear drop
  • Higher risk of postoperative pain and inflammation, hyphema and conjunctival congestion
  • Lower risk of postoperative pain, conjunctival congestion, hyphema and inflammation

Overall Accessibility

More accessible due to cost-effectiveness and versatility

Preferred in settings with better resources and where faster recovery is prioritized

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and high myopia undergoes cataract surgery. During the procedure, she suddenly experiences severe ocular pain and a rapid rise in intraocular pressure. Fundoscopic examination reveals a dark red elevation in the choroidal region. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step?

options.label: B
options.text: Increase the infusion pressure in the anterior chamber

options.label: C
options.text: Perform immediate vitrectomy to drain the hemorrhage

options.label: D
options.text: Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure

questions.correct_answer: D. Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure
questions.explanation:
Immediate

Subsequate
  • Closure of the incision with a suture to retain residual viscoelastic in the eye.
  • Diagnosis should be confirmed at the slit-lamp as soon as possible.
  • Acetazolamide to lower intraocular pressure.
  • Intensive topical and systemic steroids to reduce inflammation, with standard postoperative antibiotic treatment and IOP management.
  • Drainage, if subsequent hemorrhage fails to resolve (after 7-14 days, by which liquefaction of blood clot has taken place).
  • Pars plana vitrectomy may be considered when the retina appears adherent or detached.

questions.text: Match the images of IOL malpositions with their names: Image Syndrome a. 1. Sunrise syndrome b. 2. Lost lens syndrome c. 3. Sunset syndrome
questions.explanation:
Name

Malposition

Sunset syndrome

Inferior subluxation of IOL

Sunrise syndrome

Superior subluxation of IOL

Lost lens syndrome

Complete dislocation of an IOL into the vitreous cavity

Windshield wiper syndrome

When a very small IOL is placed vertically in the sulcus the superior loop moves to the left and right, with movements of the head

questions.text: A school-going child is diagnosed with a connective tissue disorder characterized by abnormalities of the eye, short stature, brachydactyly, joint stiffness, and cardiovascular defects. Which among the following is incorrect regarding the likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Follows autosomal recessive mode of inheritance

options.label: D
options.text: Usual age of presentation is 5-10 years

questions.correct_answer: B. Associated with supero-temporal lens dislocation
questions.explanation:
Marfan's Syndrome

Autosomal dominant

B/L Supero-temporal dislocation, Megalocornea

Arachnodactyly, long limbs, hypermobile joints, cardiovascular defects

Homocystinuria

Autosomal recessive

Infero-nasal dislocation

A/w zonular breaks and hence loss of accommodation

Detection of homocysteine in urine using the sodium nitroprusside test.

Weill-Marchesani Syndrome

Autosomal recessive (Option A)

Microspherophakia, Inferior or forward subluxation of the lens


 

Short stature, brachydactyly, joint stiffness, cardiovascular defects.

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome

Lens subluxation, blue sclera, Hyperextensible joints

Stickler Syndrome

Liquified vitreous, retinal detachment, Pre-senile cataract

Oro-facial abnormalities, arthropathy
 

Sulphite Oxidase Deficiency

Autosomal recessive

Ectopia lentis, Progressive muscular rigidity

Death usually by 5 years of age

questions.text: In which scenario is a posterior capsule tear more commonly observed during cataract surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: During phacoemulsification with high energy settings

options.label: B
options.text: During cortical clean-up with a manual irrigation-aspiration technique

options.label: D
options.text: During anterior chamber maintenance with a viscoelastic substance

questions.correct_answer: B. During cortical clean-up with a manual irrigation-aspiration technique
